text: I still see it a bit weird, FoK is for time-sensitive stuff where price is less important, but if you don't exit you care mostly about price, yet you are willing to risk suboptimal fills to get _some_ of it. Maybe i'm oversimplifying, but there's definitely something I'm missing :slightly_smiling_face:

text: You're essentially saying you're willing to give up best price execution because you're too lazy to handle cancelling your bet as soon as it's live. It's hubris to completely ignore the market

elements.text: You're essentially saying you're willing to give up best price execution because you're too lazy to handle cancelling your bet as soon as it's live. It's hubris to completely ignore the market

text: I set my price based on the current average market price - I don't look at what is at each price

elements.text: I set my price based on the current average market price - I don't look at what is at each price

text: Fill or kill is a better execution strategy over a manual fire and cancel

text: For my system I am a long way from a "finished" product, so we will go through a lot of changes over the next 1-2 years. This strategy works for what I am doing at the moment, but at some stage we will be performing far more complex betting which will entail leaving offers there for certain amounts of time

elements.text: For my system I am a long way from a "finished" product, so we will go through a lot of changes over the next 1-2 years. This strategy works for what I am doing at the moment, but at some stage we will be performing far more complex betting which will entail leaving offers there for certain amounts of time

text: Priority always is, and has been, 1) get a decent working model; 2) get a decent working execution strategy; 3) enhance everything now that we are "self-funded"

elements.text: Priority always is, and has been, 1) get a decent working model; 2) get a decent working execution strategy; 3) enhance everything now that we are "self-funded"

text: If you are betting inplay, no one will match your bet before you cancel it (because of the bet delay) so that's in favor of implementing your own fill or kill.

elements.text: If you are betting inplay, no one will match your bet before you cancel it (because of the bet delay) so that's in favor of implementing your own fill or kill.

text: You can't cancel until the bet is there. So there is always a delay while it is there. If you have other current bets you need the id of that bet to cancel

elements.text: You can't cancel until the bet is there. So there is always a delay while it is there. If you have other current bets you need the id of that bet to cancel

text: In reality it won't make much of a difference either way, which is why going for the simpler execution is the better move and leaves more time to look at other things

elements.text: In reality it won't make much of a difference either way, which is why going for the simpler execution is the better move and leaves more time to look at other things

text: Well until the bet is there you don't even know if you matched or not, so the delay exists even if you use FoK

text: Yes, but it's a single request for fill-or-kill

text: I bet up to 3 times each point, and ensuring that I don't send extra bets (did a few times early on) is THE most important thing, as it runs automated, mainly overnight while I am asleep. So a simpler execution has less to go wrong

elements.text: I bet up to 3 times each point, and ensuring that I don't send extra bets (did a few times early on) is THE most important thing, as it runs automated, mainly overnight while I am asleep. So a simpler execution has less to go wrong

text: So <@U016535QCJ2> as you use FoK and are placing huge numbers of bets maybe you can answer my question that I have not yet asked Betfair. As most people don't like FoK as implemented by Betfair seems nobody else can have as good a stab at the answer as you do. For a failed FoK bet, are you charged for a SINGLE  transaction or does it act as 2 (place bet/ cancel bet) ?
